awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding enamel hypoplasia in great apes of known life history
awd_abstract_narration:
Much like tree rings provide a record of growth patterns related to past environmental conditions, teeth can preserve a record of physiological stress experienced during dental development. This doctoral dissertation project will use novel imaging and analytical methods to study stress-related dental defects in Virunga mountain gorillas for whom long-term behavioral, health, and climate data are available. The ability to link specific dental defects to specific life events will improve our understanding of the complex interplay among ecological, social, and physiological stressors in both extant great apes and fossil hominins. The project will support student mentoring and training in STEM fields as well as collaborations and conservation efforts at the research site.  

Teeth are important to studies of health and development because they provide a permanent and detailed record of their absolute chronological growth. Enamel hypoplasias manifest as grooves on the tooth surface when growth is disrupted by stressors such as undernutrition and disease. Hypoplastic defects are usually scored by low-power enamel surface observation, and the boundary between normal and abnormal morphology has never been quantitatively defined in great apes. This project employs quantitative criteria to diagnose defects, and establishes a minimum threshold for determining what is a defect versus what is within the bounds of normal variation. Aims include: (1) determining defect presence quantitatively, and testing for differences in defect prevalence and morphology among mountain gorillas and other great apes; (2) analyzing microanatomical parameters of crown growth to determine which factors influence variation in defect morphology among great apes; and (3) testing correspondence between defect timing and stressful events (e.g. injury, disease, intergroup interactions) in the recorded history of individual mountain gorillas to produce the first data on enamel hypoplasia etiology in wild gorillas. By assessing the relationships between defect morphology, microanatomical parameters of enamel growth, and documented stressors in associated life history records, the proposed research will deepen our understanding of factors that underlie differences in defect expression among great apes, and thus improve our ability to more confidently interpret enamel defects in paleoanthropological contexts.

por.por_cntn:
Kate McGrath completed her dissertation research, "Understanding enamel hypoplasia in great apes of known life history," which was supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG). She spent the first several months of the funding period collecting data at the University of Tübingen, the University of Zürich, and the Royal College of Surgeons. She used quantitative techniques to characterize enamel defects that occur on the outer tooth surface, and are common signs of early life stress in great apes and humans.

Linear enamel hypoplasia or LEH is a condition characterized by horizontal grooves around tooth crowns (Figure 1). Previous studies report that >75% of great ape canines have at least one LEH defect. The only exception is Virunga mountain gorillas, which were shown to have far fewer defects (~10%) than other great ape species. The authors hypothesized that Virunga mountain gorillas, which live at an ecological extreme among great apes, might experience less early life stress compared to other species, or that they might grow their canines more quickly and thus have shallower defects that are harder to reliably identify using qualitative methods.

This dissertation has three main chapters, in which Kate developed a new method to quantify LEH defects in Virunga mountain gorillas and other species. She found that, as predicted, mountain gorillas have shallower defects than other great apes. Females were found to have deeper defects than males. These within- and between-species differences in defect depth are presumably related to differences in growth rates, so the second chapter incorporated histological thin sections to assess canine growth patterns in these same groups. She found that LEH defect depth correlates with variation in canine growth patterns between sexes and species, with mountain gorillas growing their canines at faster rates than other great apes, and males growing their canines faster than females. The third chapter focused on Virunga mountain gorillas with associated health records to assess whether stressful events in early life correspond to LEH defect formation. The dates of three known poaching-related snare removals were found to correspond to defect formation in the canines of two individuals.

This work increases our understanding of what kinds of stress are associated with the formation of LEH defects in wild primates. It develops new methods that can be applied to other species, including modern humans and fossil hominins, to better understand dental development and stress histories of past populations. It also connects dental growth patterns with LEH defect morphology on the outer enamel surface, thus shedding light on the extent to which LEH defect depth reflects stress severity in great apes. Taken together, these results suggest that sex- and species-specific growth patterns heavily influence LEH defect depth, but that outliers might represent episodes of more severe stress. One example of the latter is a case in which a wild-captured western lowland gorilla demonstrates the deepest LEH defect in the comparative sample, and the developmental timing of this defect likely corresponds to her capture from the wild as an infant. Future research will continue to tease apart the relative contribution of dental growth patterns vs. life experiences in defect formation in great apes of known life history so that more can be gleaned from the fossil record than is currently possible.

Kate shared these results with her community and the public through several avenues. She participated in over 400 hours of public outreach in museums, schools, and events during graduate school. Some examples include participating in the Scientist is In program at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, in which Kate talked about human evolution with visitors to the Human Origins Exhibit alongside touchable objects once or twice per year. As part of her Public Understanding of Science internship, she developed a series of lesson plans about human evolution, including a lesson on this research, for K-12 students. She taught these lessons in public and private schools in Atlanta, New Orleans, and Austin with the American Association of Physical Anthropologists Education Committee. She primarily served members of underrepresented groups in her outreach and mentoring, and worked with local high school and undergraduate students from DC and Virginia as interns and mentees. Several mentees have since gone on to pursue competitive graduate degrees in nursing, medicine, and biological anthropology.
